sections.title: CBCT and 3D dental scanning
sections.body:
Three-dimensional scanning allows us to see dental structures in more detail than traditional two-dimensional X-rays.

CBCT (cone beam computed tomography) provides a 3D view of teeth, bone, nerves, and surrounding anatomy. It’s used selectively, when additional information genuinely helps with diagnosis or planning.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, CBCT scanning is used to support careful decision-making — not as a routine step for every patient.
bullets: Shows teeth, bone, nerves, and surrounding anatomy
Used selectively when extra information helps
Supports careful decision-making, not routine scanning

sections.title: When CBCT scanning may be recommended
items: Standard X-rays do not provide enough information
Implant planning or assessment of bone quality and anatomy
Complex extractions or impacted teeth
Root-treated teeth with ongoing symptoms
Jaw or facial pain requiring detailed assessment

sections.title: What 3D scanning shows that standard X-rays don’t
sections.body:
Unlike traditional X-rays, CBCT scans show structures in three dimensions.

This can help us assess bone thickness and shape, the position of nerves and sinuses, the extent of infection or fractures, and how teeth relate to surrounding structures.

Having this information upfront helps reduce uncertainty and improve planning accuracy.
bullets: See the position of nerves and sinuses
Review the extent of infection or fractures
Understand how teeth relate to surrounding structures
Reduce uncertainty and improve planning accuracy

sections.title: Planning and safety
items: Scans are used when the benefit outweighs the risk
We follow UK guidance on justification and exposure
Scan area and settings are selected to minimise exposure
Supports safer, more predictable planning for complex care
We’re happy to discuss radiation levels before proceeding

sections.title: What to expect during a scan
items: We explain the scan and answer questions before starting
You stand or sit still while the scanner rotates briefly
The scan takes seconds and is non-invasive
There is no contact or discomfort during the scan
Results are reviewed alongside your examination and records
sections.strapline: A CBCT scan is quick and non-invasive.

sections.title: How scan results are used
sections.body:
Scan results are used to support diagnosis and planning — not to replace clinical judgement.

They may help confirm whether treatment is appropriate, refine the proposed approach, or highlight situations where an alternative plan is safer.

We’ll explain what the scan shows and how it influences recommendations.

sections.title: When a CBCT scan isn’t needed
items: Not every dental problem requires 3D imaging
Standard X-rays and clinical examination may be sufficient
A CBCT scan won’t be recommended if information is clear
Our aim is to use the simplest appropriate tools
We explain the reasoning for any imaging decision

faqs.question: Why might a CBCT scan be recommended?
faqs.answer: CBCT scanning is advised when standard X-rays don’t provide enough information, such as implant planning, complex extractions, impacted teeth, or ongoing symptoms after root treatment.

faqs.question: Do I need a CBCT scan for every problem?
faqs.answer: Not every dental problem requires 3D imaging. If standard X-rays and clinical examination provide sufficient information, a CBCT scan won’t be recommended.

faqs.question: How are scan results used?
faqs.answer: Results support diagnosis and planning, helping confirm whether treatment is appropriate, refine the proposed approach, or highlight when an alternative plan is safer.

faqs.question: Can I ask about radiation and safety?
faqs.answer: Yes. We follow UK guidance on justification and exposure, use settings that minimise dose, and are happy to discuss radiation levels before proceeding.

faqs.question: What happens during the scan?
faqs.answer: You’ll stand or sit still while the scanner rotates briefly around your head. The scan takes seconds and is non-invasive, with no contact or discomfort.

sections.title: Questions or concerns
sections.body:
If you’re unsure why a CBCT scan has been suggested, or whether it’s necessary, we encourage you to ask.

Understanding the reason for any investigation is an important part of informed decision-making.
bullets: We explain why a scan may be helpful in your case
You can ask about alternatives and whether it is necessary
